","post_number":3,"post_type":1,"posts_count":5,"updated_at":"2024-10-28T14:11:04.419Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":2,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":153,"readers_count":152,"score":35.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":473880,"topic_slug":"how-do-you-make-lights-turn-on-after-a-certain-rev-on-the-talon-fx","display_username":"jace","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":9105,"username":"Fletch1373","name":"Fletch","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/fletch1373/{size}/220073_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":68704,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Worlds alrightest programmer "},"post_url":"/t/how-do-you-make-lights-turn-on-after-a-certain-rev-on-the-talon-fx/473880/3","custom_user_title":"Worlds alrightest programmer ","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3440759,"name":"Fletch","username":"Fletch1373","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/fletch1373/{size}/220073_2.png","created_at":"2024-10-28T16:58:23.923Z","cooked":"

Break the problem down into smaller pieces.

  1. Identify the “trigger” for the change you want
  2. Perform the change

For 1, the trigger you seem to want is “after motor has turned __ times”. How might you get that information? What features are available from the motor/motor controller you’re using? If nothing useful, you may need to add an additional feedback sensor (likely an encoder) to get that information.

For 2, sounds like you already have it. If you can turn the lights on and off from a button press, then you’re good to go here. Just change the “button press” part to whatever condition you build from step 1 above

Fletch1373:

What features are available from the motor/motor controller you’re using? If nothing useful, you may need to add an additional feedback sensor (likely an encoder) to get that information.

Every Talon FX controller that has ever been shipped has been shipped permanently attached to a motor (either the Falcon 500, Kraken X60, or soon the Kraken X44) with an integrated encoder. For OP’s use case, this part would be thoroughly covered.

(Talon FXS could theoretically be used with a brushed motor that lacks such an encoder, but that controller hasn’t shipped yet and I’d expect that use to be exceedingly rare.)
